questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for the development of surgical site infections except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hypercholesterolemia is not a recognised risk factor for surgical site infection, whereas hypocholestrolemia is considered so.

Cholesterol's Role in Immune Defense:

  • Cell Membrane Integrity: Cholesterol is essential for maintaining the structure and function of immune cell membranes (e.g., macrophages, neutrophils). Low cholesterol may impair their ability to migrate, phagocytose bacteria, and produce antimicrobial peptides.
  • Inflammatory Response Modulation: Cholesterol is a precursor for steroid hormones and bile acids, which influence immune regulation. Low levels may lead to dysregulated inflammation, impairing wound healing.
  • LPS (Endotoxin) Binding: LDL and HDL bind and neutralize bacterial lipopolysaccharides (LPS), reducing systemic inflammation. Hypocholesterolemia may increase susceptibility to infections by allowing endotoxins to circulate freely.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most commonly acquired Hospital infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

There are four groups of infection which are usually hospital acquired:

  • Respiratory infections (including ventilator-associated pneumonia)
  • Urinary tract infection (mostly related to urinary catheters, it is the most Common hospital-acquired infection) (Option A, C, D ruled out).
  • Bacteremia (mostly related to indwelling vascular catheters)
  • Surgical site infections

questions.text: After undergoing hip replacement surgery, for what duration of time should a patient be followed up on to avoid Surgical site infections (SSIs)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • CDC/NHSN Guidelines classify prosthetic joint infections (e.g., hip replacements) as "deep incisional/organ-space SSIs", requiring 1 year (365 days) of surveillance.
  • Implants create a niche for biofilm-forming bacteria (e.g., aureus, CoNS), which can cause delayed infections (months post-op).
  • Key monitoring: ESR/CRP, joint pain, fever, or wound discharge beyond 30 days.
  • Non-prosthetic surgeries: Superficial SSIs typically monitored for 30 days.

choices.text: It more commonly occurs due to streptococci
If not treated early, it leads to systemic signs and symptoms

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient admitted in the surgical unit developed swelling and blisters on the leg as shown in the picture below. All of the following statements are correct regarding the condition except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This is image shows cellulitis of the leg, commonly caused due to β-Hemolytic streptococci (Option A ruled out). Other organisms that can lead to this are staphylococci and C. perfrigens.
  • It is a non-suppurative invasive infection of soft tissue which has no edge, no fluctuation and no limit.
  • Cellulitis is associated with fever, chills, and general fatigue. If the infection is left untreated, cellulitis can result in development of abscesses, and lead to the release of toxins into circulation, which presents with systemic signs and symptoms like chills, fever and rigors (Option C ruled out).
  • Lymphangitis is part of a similar process and presents as painful red streaks in affected lymphatics draining the source of infection. It is often accompanied by painful lymph node groups in the related drainage area (Option D ruled out).

Lymphangitis infection of leg:

choices.text: It can be caused by clostridial or non-clostridial pathogens
On gram stain organism will be present as gram positive bacilli
Antibiotic prophylaxis is not necessary as amputation will be required
It spreads rapidly if not treated due to release of various collagenase and alpha toxin

questions.text: Mr. X, a known diabetic, comes to the surgery OPD with a mal-odorous, erythematous and edematous left foot lesion as shown in the image below. He gives a history of trauma due to a road traffic accident 4 days ago, and said that after 3 days, shooting pains radiated up his left leg to his back. He also has symptoms like fever and chills, along with nausea and vomiting. All of the following statements are correct about this condition except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

From the clinical history and image shown, the diagnosis would be in the favour of Gas gangrene. Gangrene spreads rapidly due to the release of collagenase, hyaluronidase, other proteases and alpha toxin.

Gas gangrene occurs more commonly due to clostridial species but can also be caused due to non-clostridial organisms. Clostridial species more commonly lead to gas gangrene with C. Perfringens as the main causative organism. C.Novyi, C.Septicum or C.ramnosum, and less commonly, Klebsiella pneumoniae can also lead to gas gangrene in Diabetic patients (Option A ruled out).

On Gram stain, it appears as Gram-positive, anaerobic, spore-bearing bacilli (Option B ruled out). Gram stain can confirm the organisms immediately, while other culture methods might take time, which is why it is not preferred.

It is advisable to start antibiotic prophylaxis immediately without waiting for culture (Option C ruled out). Broad spectrum antibiotic containing penicillin should be started and should be continued in perioperative period, even though amputation is performed.

choices.text: It occurs due to anaerobic gram-positive spore-bearing bacilli
Clinical features of it are produced by exotoxin acting on motor neurons of the posterior horn of the spinal cord
Toxicity depends on the prodromal period
Toxoid should be given in three separate doses to give protection for 5 years, following which a booster dose is required

questions.text: All of the following are correct regarding tetanus except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The signs and symptoms are produced by the release of the Exotoxin - Tetanospasmin, which affects Myoneural junction and motor neurons of the anterior horn of the spinal cord.

Tetanus is caused by Clostridium tetani which is anaerobic gram positive spore bearing bacilli (Option A ruled out).

Disease severity depends on the prodromal period. A short prodromal period, which has a poor prognosis, leads to spasms in the distribution of theshort motor nerves ;of the face, followed by the development of severe generalised motor spasms, including Opisthotonus, respiratory arrest and death. A longer prodromal period of 4-5 weeks is associated with a milder form of the disease ( Option C ruled out).

The toxoid is a formalin-attenuated vaccine and should be given in three separate dosesto give protection for a 5-year period, after which a single5-yearly boosterconfers immunity. It should be given to all patients with open traumatic wounds who are not immunised. At-risk wounds are those when there is late presentation, when there isdevitalization oftissue or when there is wound soiling. For these wounds, a booster of toxoid should be given or, if the patient is not immunised at all, a three-dose course is given together with prophylactic benzylpenicillin (Option D ruled out).

questions.text: The criteria for SIRS include all of the following except:
questions.solution: Explanation:

choices.text: It is also known as synergistic spreading gangrene
Subdermal spread is faster than superficial spread
Pain, Gangrene, crepitus and smell are characteristic of this condition
Removal of the scrotum with the testes must be done to clear infection

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a known case of diabetes presented to the surgical OPD with swollen, blackened Scrotum, as shown below in the picture. All of the following statements about the condition are correct except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The condition in the picture shown is that of Fourniergangrene. It is more common in;Diabetic and ;Immunosuppressed It occurs due to polymicrobial infection in which aerobic bacteria destroy living tissue, allowing anaerobic bacteria to thrive, leading to synergistic spreading gangrene (Option A ruled out).
  • It primarily affect the subcutaneoustissue, so it spreads rapidly in the the Subdermal space. Thus, during debridement, wide excision of tissue more than skin is done to remove infection, which is more likely to spread in the subdermal space than skin (Option B ruled out).
  • Severe wound pain, signs of spreading inflammation with crepitus, gangrene and smell are characteristic of spreading Fournier gangrene (Option C ruled out).
  • Testes should be removed as Fournier affects the scrotum, not the testes. In case of inefficient vascularity or spreading to testes, it would have to be removed.

choices.text: Preoperative skin shaving should be done in the operating theatre immediately before surgery
Hair clipping is the best method for shaving
Alcohol hand gel is more effective than hand washing with soap, and it should be given priority over hand washing with soap
A Short preoperative hospital stay is ideal before surgery

questions.text: All of the following are correct regarding preoperative operation except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hand washing is more effective than any other method. Alcohol hand gel is ineffective against Clostridium difficile. Soap plus povidone iodine is ideal for hand washing.

If Skin shaving is performed the night before, the rate of SSI doubles because minor skin injury enhances superficial bacterial colonisation. So, preoperative skin shaving should be done in the operating theatre immediately before surgery (Option A ruled out).

Hair clipping is the best method with the lowest infection rate (Option B ruled out). Cream depilation is messy and increases risk of infection..

A short preoperative hospital stay lowers the risk of acquiring MRSA, Multiple resistant coagulase-negative staphylococci and other antibiotic-resistant organisms from the hospital environment (Option D ruled out).

questions.text: Ideal time to give preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Antibiotics should be given in such a way that maximum blood and tissue levels of the antibiotic is present before making an incision. So, the ideal time to give antibiotics is 1 hour before surgery.

questions.text: You are performing a laparotomy for a case of bowel obstruction in which enterotomy is to be performed. Without antibiotic prophylaxis, what would be the expected rate of infection in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Performing an enterotomy for bowel obstruction is considered to be a Contaminated Surgery.

questions.text: A patient comes to your OPD with a history of blood in stools. You decide to do a colonoscopy and observe collar stud ulcers. Which of the following would be the diagnosis based on your observation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • 'Collar stud' or 'flask-shaped' ulcer is the characteristic of Amoebic dysentry, caused by Entamoeba Hystolytica.
  • The amoebic infection leads to intestinal ulcers, bleeding, increased mucus production and diarrhoea
  • Thefeeding process of the organism involves the production of tissue-dissolving secretions (histolysin), which are responsible for these intestinal ulcers.

Collar-stud ulcer on Barium enema:

choices.text: Patient should be given a double dose of antibiotic to resolve infection
Radiological resolution occurs immediately once the antibiotic is started
Luminal amoebicide should be given to clear the cysts from the intestinal cavity

questions.text: A 46-year-old man with a history of travel, presented to the OPD with complaints of lower abdominal pain, anorexia, fever and diarrhoea. After a few days, he develops pain in the right upper abdomen. CT scan shows the following findings. All of the following are correct regarding the management of this condition except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • According to the clinical history and CT scan findings, this is most likely a case of Amoebic abscess. Even if the infection subsides, radiological resolution takes3 to 6 monthsto clear.
  • For treatment of amoebic abscess, double dose of IV Metronidazole or Tinidazole is started (Option A ruled out). Luminal amoebicide must be included after infection has been controlled in liver to clear the cysts from the intestinal cavity (Option D ruled out).
  • Glissons capsuleis resistant to enzymatic digestion by trophozoites. So, the capsule does not breach easily and abscess presents as a subcapsular abscess ,and the chances of rupture is less than pyogenic abscess (Option C ruled out).

choices.text: These symptoms occur due to infestation by the adult form of the organism
Small bowel obstruction can occur due to incarceration of adult forms.
Surgery is the first line of treatment for him.
Albendazole is the drug of choice for roundworm.

questions.text: A malnourished 10-year-old child has come with complaints of bilious vomiting and abdominal pain. Under your advice, he has undergone a barium meal to find the cause of his symptoms, which shows the findings as shown in the image. All of the following statements are correct regarding this condition except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This Barium meal shows Roundworms in the small intestine. Intestinal symptoms would occur usually due to adult forms of round worms while pulmonary symptoms would occur due to larval form (Option A ruled out).

Conservative treatment with anthelmintics is the first line of treatment even in obstruction. Surgery is not generally indicated.

Due to incarceration of bolus by the adult roundworms, small Intestinal obstruction can occur, particularly in children (Option B ruled out).

Albendazole is the drug of choice as anthelmintic for roundworm infestation (Option D ruled out).

choices.text: The causative organism resides in snail, which acts asthe intermediate host.
Intra-hepatic bile duct stones also occur due to this parasite.
Confirmation of condition can be done by USG or a urine sample showing parasite.
Surgical exploration with removal of gall bladder + exploration of CBD and repeated washout + choledochoduodenostomy is indicated.

questions.text: A Young male presents with a history of fever and jaundice. He also has h/o passage of recurrent white thread-like structures in stool. USG was s/o 9 cm long CBD structure with 9 mm CBD diameter and proximal dilation of the biliary tree. All of the following are correct regarding it except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical history and USG findings are suggestive of a case of Clonorchis sinensis causing Cholangiohepatitis. Snailsand Fish act as intermediate hosts for this organism (Option A ruled out).
  • Intra-hepatic bile duct stones are also caused by the parasite producing Mucinrich bile (Option B ruled out). Intrahepatic bile ducts are dilated with epithelial hyperplasia and peri-ductal fibrosis. These changes may lead to dysplasia causing cholangiocarcinoma.
  • Confirmation of the condition requires examination of ;stoolor duodenal aspirate , which may show the eggs or adult worms. USG may have characteristic findings of uniform dilation of small peripheral intrahepatic bile ducts with only minimal dilation of the common hepatic and common bile duct. But it is not confirmatory.
  • Cholecystectomywith exploration of the common bile duct is performed when indicated. Repeated washouts are necessary during the exploration, as the common bile duct is dilated and contains stones, biliary debris, sludge and mud. This should be followed by choledochoduodenostomy (Option D ruled out).

choices.text: This is a type I cyst, which is composed of three layers: inner endocyst, intermediate ectocyst and outer pericyst.
In case of cyst rupture, anaphylactic shock can develop.
Casoni's test, which is a type II hypersensitivity test, is used to confirm the disease.
PAIR is the ideal method of management for this case

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presented with pain in the right upper abdomen and rash over the abdomen. With the help of antihistamines rash disappears, but the pain persists even after painkillers. A CT abdomen was done, which shows the following findings. All of the statements are correct regarding it except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical history suggests a case of a Hydatid cyst. CT scan shows type I Hydatid cyst composed of three layers:
    • Inner endocyst, that contains the germinal membrane
    • Intermediate ectocyst
    • Outer pericyst derived from compressed host organ tissue (Option A ruled out).
  • Due to the high antigenicity of hydatid fluid, if cyst ruptures, patients develop severe anaphylactic shock (Option B ruled out) .
  • Casoni's test, which is not currently used, is a type I hypersensitivity
  • PAIR (Puncture, Aspiration, Injection and Re-aspiration) would be ideal as there is no septation and it is less invasive (Option D ruled out).

questions.text: Which among the following is not a component of the seroma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Seroma:

  • A seroma is the collection of fluid containing fat, serum, and lymph that develops at a surgical wound or dead space from surgery.
  • Seromas are common in surgical procedures, which create dead space or interruption of lymphatic drainage.
  • Examples of this include breast or axillary surgery and hernia surgery.
  • The use of prosthetic mesh in hernia surgery may contribute to poor flap adherence and trigger inflammation, which can increase the risk of seroma formation.

choices.text: Give antibiotics to all other patients in the ward
Disinfect the ward with sodium hypochlorite

questions.text: In a post-operative intensive care unit, 5 patients developed postoperative wound infection on the same wound. The best method to prevent cross-infection occurring in other patients in the same ward is to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hand hygiene is considered a primary measure for reducing the risk of transmitting infection among patients and health care personnel.
  • Hand hygiene procedures include the use of alcohol-based hand rubs (containing 60%-95% alcohol) and hand washing with soap and water.
  • For surgical procedures, perform a surgical hand scrub before putting on sterile surgeon's gloves.
  • For routine dental examinations and nonsurgical procedures, use an alcohol-based hand rub or use water and plain or antimicrobial soap specific for health care settings.
  • Unless hands are visibly soiled (e.g. dirt, blood, body fluids), an alcohol-based hand rub is preferred over soap and water in most clinical situations.

Hand hygiene should be performed in the following situations:

  • Before and after treating each patient (e.g., before and after gloving).
  • After touching with bare hands instruments, equipment, materials, and other objects that are likely to be contaminated by blood, saliva, or respiratory secretions.
  • Before leaving the dental treatment area.
  • When hands are visibly soiled.
  • Before regloving and after removing gloves that are torn, cut, or punctured.

Incorrect options:

Options A, B, C are neither practical nor effective in preventing cross-contamination between patients.
